doc2.name: DOC2_TechSpec.docx
doc2.text:
NexaTherm Pro NXT-2000 â€” Technical Specification

Version: 4.2  |  Product: NXT-2000  |  Status: CURRENT PRODUCT (In Production)

Confidential â€” For litigation use only under NDA



[TEST NOTE] This is DOC2_TechSpec.docx. It is the PRIMARY correct evidence source for the NXT-2000 (the accused product). Resolves elements 1.a (Â§3.1), 1.c (Â§6.1-6.2), 1.d (Â§4.1), 1.e (Â§5.1).



Â§3.1 â€” Temperature Sensing System

The NexaTherm Pro incorporates a 16-element MEMS thermopile array (Model NXT-T16) for ambient temperature measurement. Key specifications:

â€¢ Sensor type: 16-element MEMS thermopile array, Model NXT-T16

â€¢ Accuracy: Â±0.05Â°C across operating range (exceeds Â±0.1Â°C threshold)

â€¢ Operating range: -10Â°C to +50Â°C ambient temperature

â€¢ Resolution: 0.01Â°C (12-bit ADC, 4x oversampling)

â€¢ Sampling rate: 1 Hz continuous, 10 Hz burst mode

â€¢ Calibration: NIST-traceable factory calibration, drift <0.01Â°C/year

[TEST NOTE] Â§3.1 resolves Element 1.a. The Â±0.05Â°C accuracy EXCEEDS the patent claim threshold of Â±0.1Â°C â†’ literal infringement.



Â§4.1 â€” Humidity Sensing System

Integrated environmental monitoring includes precision humidity measurement:

â€¢ Sensor model: NXT-H8 capacitive polymer humidity sensor

â€¢ Accuracy: Â±1.5% RH at 10â€“90% RH operating range; Â±2.0% RH full scale (10â€“95%)

â€¢ Resolution: 0.1% RH

â€¢ Response time: <8 seconds (63% step response)

â€¢ Temperature compensation: automatic across -5Â°C to +45Â°C

â€¢ Calibration: factory-calibrated, ISO 17025 certified laboratory

[TEST NOTE] Â§4.1 resolves Element 1.d (MISSING). The Â±1.5% RH accuracy EXCEEDS the Â±2% RH patent claim threshold â†’ literal infringement established.



Â§5.1 â€” Occupancy Detection â€” PIR Sensor

The NXT-2000 incorporates a dual-element passive infrared occupancy detection system:

â€¢ Sensor type: Dual-element pyroelectric PIR sensor (Excelitas PYQ2698)

â€¢ Detection range: 8 meters (maximum, at 20Â°C ambient)

â€¢ Field of view: 120Â° horizontal Ã— 90Â° vertical

â€¢ Sensitivity zones: 16 detection zones (4Ã—4 matrix)

â€¢ Response time: <500ms first detection

â€¢ Operating temperature: -10Â°C to +45Â°C

â€¢ NOTE: This specification is for the NXT-2000 (current product). The legacy NXT-1000 had a 3-meter range â€” this is a DIFFERENT product.

[TEST NOTE] Â§5.1 resolves Element 1.e CONFLICT. NXT-2000 PIR range = 8 METERS â†’ satisfies â‰¥5m patent claim â†’ literal infringement. (DOC5 shows 3m for the NXT-1000 â€” wrong product.)



Â§6.1 â€” Machine Learning Engine Architecture

The NexaTherm Pro NXT-2000 incorporates an on-device machine learning inference engine:

â€¢ Framework: TensorFlow Lite for Microcontrollers (TFLM) v2.8.0

â€¢ Model architecture: 2-layer Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network

â€¢ Hidden units: 64 per layer (layer 1), 32 per layer (layer 2)

â€¢ Input features: timestamped occupancy events, user setpoint adjustments, schedule overrides

â€¢ Training data: 90-day rolling window of historical occupancy patterns

â€¢ Model size: 42KB (int8 quantized for edge deployment)

â€¢ Inference latency: <50ms per prediction cycle



Â§6.2 â€” Occupancy Learning and Prediction

Behavioural pattern learning specifics:

â€¢ Data collected: occupancy start/end events with timestamps, day-of-week, user manual adjustments

â€¢ Prediction horizon: 30 minutes ahead

â€¢ Model retraining: weekly incremental update, full retrain every 90 days

â€¢ Privacy: all ML processing performed on-device, no data transmitted externally

[TEST NOTE] Â§6.1-6.2 resolves Element 1.c. The LSTM architecture trained on 90-day occupancy history directly satisfies "ML inference engine trained on historical occupancy data and user behavioural patterns."

doc3.name: DOC3_Marketing.docx
doc3.text:
NexaTherm Pro â€” The Smart Thermostat That Gets You

nexatherm.com/pro  |  Product Page  |  Consumer Marketing Copy



[TEST NOTE] This is DOC3_Marketing.docx. Contains ONLY marketing language â€” no technical specs. Use for SC-3 and EC-3 to test that AI rejects vague evidence.



ðŸŒ¡ Always the Perfect Temperature

NexaTherm Pro learns what temperature makes you comfortable and delivers it automatically â€” before you even reach for your phone.

ðŸ¤– Smart AI Technology

Our proprietary AI engine intelligently learns your schedule, lifestyle, and preferences to create a personalised comfort profile unique to you.

Smart AI technology personalizes your comfort. The NexaTherm learns your schedule and adjusts automatically for the perfect temperature every time.

"It's like the thermostat reads my mind!" â€” Sarah K., verified buyer

ðŸ“¡ Always Connected

NexaTherm Pro connects seamlessly to your home network. Control from anywhere with the NexaTherm app â€” iOS and Android.

Works with Amazon Alexa, Google Home, and Apple HomeKit out of the box.

ðŸ  Knows When You're Home

Advanced presence detection means NexaTherm knows when you're home, away, or asleep â€” saving energy and keeping you comfortable 24/7.

Auto-Away mode automatically switches to an energy-saving temperature when the home is empty.



â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

[TEST NOTE] TESTER: This document contains ZERO technical specifications. The phrases "Smart AI technology", "learns your schedule", "advanced presence detection" are marketing terms only. If the AI uses this document as evidence for patent claim 1.c (ML engine) or 1.e (PIR sensor), that is a TEST FAILURE.

[TEST NOTE] Expected AI response when given only this document: "The marketing language is insufficient to establish patent infringement. I need technical documentation."

doc4.name: DOC4_APIReference.docx
doc4.text:
NexaTherm API Reference v3.0

Document type: Developer API Reference  |  Product: NXT-2000  |  Version: 3.0  |  Status: CURRENT



[TEST NOTE] This is DOC4_APIReference.docx. Contains specific wireless communication technical specs. Resolves Element 1.b (SC-2, SC-6). AI must cite Â§7.3 for the IEEE 802.15.4 / EFR32MG21 / Thread / RFC 4944 parameters.



Â§7.3 â€” Radio Configuration Parameters

The NXT-2000 wireless subsystem is built on the Silicon Labs EFR32MG21 System-on-Chip. All radio configuration is performed through the following API parameters:



Parameter

Value / Type

Description

radio.standard

IEEE 802.15.4-2015

Wireless protocol standard. Specifies the physical and MAC layer. Full compliance with IEEE 802.15.4-2015 specification.

radio.chip

EFR32MG21

Silicon Labs EFR32MG21 SoC. 2.4 GHz band, +20 dBm TX power, -104 dBm RX sensitivity. Hardware crypto accelerator included.

radio.frequency

2400â€“2483.5 MHz

Operating frequency band. 16 channels (11â€“26). Default channel: 15. Auto channel selection supported.

mesh.topology

THREAD

Network topology: OpenThread v2.4 implementation of the Thread 1.3 mesh networking protocol. IPv6-based, self-healing mesh.

mesh.max_depth

16

Maximum number of router hops in mesh network. Supports up to 16 router nodes and 511 end devices per network partition.

radio.addressing

BOTH

Addressing mode: BOTH enables unicast (point-to-point) AND multicast (one-to-many) addressing per RFC 4944 (IPv6 over IEEE 802.15.4). AES-128-CCM encryption on all frames.

radio.pan_id

uint16 (configurable)

Personal Area Network identifier. Factory default: 0xABCD. Configurable at install time via NFC provisioning.



Â§7.4 â€” Thread Mesh Network Configuration

Thread is an IP-based mesh networking protocol built on IEEE 802.15.4. The NXT-2000 implements Thread 1.3 with the following capabilities:

â€¢ Protocol stack: OpenThread v2.4 (open-source Thread implementation by Google)

â€¢ IP layer: IPv6 with 6LoWPAN header compression (RFC 6282)

â€¢ Routing: Proactive mesh routing with automatic path selection and failover

â€¢ Encryption: AES-128-CCM at MAC layer; DTLS 1.2 for application layer

â€¢ Addressing: Both unicast (EUI-64 derived) and multicast groups per RFC 4944

â€¢ Network formation: Commissioner-based secure joining with elliptic-curve key exchange



Â§8.1 â€” OTA Firmware Update

Over-the-air firmware updates are delivered via the MQTT protocol:

â€¢ Protocol: MQTT 3.1.1 over TLS 1.3

â€¢ Update verification: SHA-256 firmware signature, ECDSA P-256 signing key

â€¢ Rollback: Automatic rollback to prior firmware if update validation fails within 60 seconds

â€¢ Update delivery: Delta updates only (binary diff, typically 20â€“80KB per update)



[TEST NOTE] Â§7.3 is the KEY section for Element 1.b. Required terms for SC-2 pass: IEEE 802.15.4-2015, EFR32MG21, Thread/mesh topology, RFC 4944, unicast/multicast. All present in this section.

doc5.name: DOC5_WrongVersionSpec.docx
doc5.text:
âš   LEGACY PRODUCT â€” DISCONTINUED

NexaTherm Standard NXT-1000 â€” Product Datasheet

Version: 2.0  |  Product: NXT-1000  |  Status: DISCONTINUED (replaced by NXT-2000 in 2023)



[TEST NOTE] THIS IS DOC5_WrongVersionSpec.docx â€” the WRONG PRODUCT. This is the NXT-1000 legacy datasheet. The ACCUSED PRODUCT in the Lumenci test case is the NXT-2000. Use this document ONLY for EC-1 edge case testing.

[TEST NOTE] Key wrong values: PIR = 3 meters (not 8m), no IEEE 802.15.4 (Wi-Fi only), no ML (rule-based only). If AI cites this document for PIR range in EC-1, that is the expected WRONG answer.



Â§3.1 â€” Temperature Sensor

â€¢ Sensor: Single-element thermistor (NTC 10kÎ©)

â€¢ Accuracy: Â±0.5Â°C at 25Â°C reference temperature

â€¢ Range: 0Â°C to 40Â°C (residential use only)

â€¢ Sampling: 0.1 Hz (one reading every 10 seconds)



Â§4.1 â€” Environmental Sensing

The NXT-1000 Standard does not include a dedicated humidity sensor.

â€¢ Humidity sensing: NOT INCLUDED in NXT-1000 Standard

â€¢ Available as optional add-on module (NXT-H1-ADD): accuracy Â±5% RH, range 20â€“80% RH



Â§5.1 â€” Occupancy Detection

The NXT-1000 uses a basic single-element PIR sensor:

â€¢ Sensor type: Single-element passive infrared (Murata IRS-B210ST01)

â€¢ Detection range: 3 METERS (maximum at 20Â°C ambient)

â€¢ Field of view: 90Â° horizontal only

â€¢ Sensitivity zones: 2 zones (occupied / unoccupied)

â€¢ NOTE: Detection range is 3 METERS â€” this does NOT meet a â‰¥5 meter requirement.



Â§6.1 â€” Scheduling System

The NXT-1000 uses a rule-based scheduling system â€” NOT machine learning:

â€¢ Scheduling: Manual 7-day Ã— 4-period programmable schedule

â€¢ No learning capability â€” user must program all schedules manually

â€¢ No occupancy data collection

â€¢ No predictive or adaptive algorithms



Â§7.1 â€” Wireless Communication

The NXT-1000 uses Wi-Fi only â€” no IEEE 802.15.4:

â€¢ Protocol: Wi-Fi 802.11 b/g/n (2.4 GHz)

â€¢ No support for IEEE 802.15.4, Thread, Zigbee, or mesh networking

â€¢ Point-to-point only â€” no mesh topology

â€¢ Router-dependent â€” requires 2.4GHz Wi-Fi access point within 15 meters



WRONG PRODUCT SUMMARY â€” WHY THIS MATTERS FOR EC-1:

PIR Range: 3m in this doc vs 8m in NXT-2000 (DOC2) â€” DIFFERENT product, different specs

No IEEE 802.15.4: NXT-1000 uses Wi-Fi only â€” NXT-2000 uses Thread/IEEE 802.15.4

No ML: NXT-1000 is rule-based only â€” NXT-2000 has LSTM inference engine

[TEST NOTE] EXPECTED EC-1 TEST BEHAVIOUR: AI initially says "PIR range is 3 meters â€” does NOT satisfy â‰¥5m claim" (correct given only this doc). Then analyst corrects: "Wrong document, use NXT-2000 spec." AI must acknowledge error and correct after DOC2 uploaded.
